articles.headline: Sales Slow for Homes New and Old
articles.snippet: A variety of experts say the housing industry appears to be moving from a boom to something that is starting to look a lot like a bust.
articles.abstract: A variety of experts say the housing industry appears to be moving from a boom to something that is starting to look a lot like a bust.
articles.lead_paragraph: Selling a new home is getting harder and harder: just ask the builders who are being forced these days to entice potential buyers with expensive inducements like free swimming pools and fancy kitchen cabinets.

articles.headline: Heart Pill to Be Sold by Itself
articles.snippet: Previously, Pfizer had said it would sell the new heart treatment only in combination with Lipitor.
articles.abstract: Previously, Pfizer had said it would sell the new heart treatment only in combination with Lipitor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reversing a strategy that had drawn criticism from doctors, Pfizer says that it will apply for approval to sell a promising new heart treatment as a standalone pill — rather than only in combination with Lipitor, Pfizer’s best-selling cholesterol treatment.

articles.headline: Israel to Occupy Area of Lebanon as Security Zone
articles.snippet: As the war between Israel and Hezbollah continued, four unarmed U.N. observers were killed when an Israeli airstrike hit their observation post near the Israeli border.
articles.abstract: As the war between Israel and Hezbollah continued, four unarmed U.N. observers were killed when an Israeli airstrike hit their observation post near the Israeli border.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, July 25 — Almost two weeks into its military assault on Hezbollah, Israel said Tuesday that it would occupy a strip inside southern Lebanon with ground troops until an international force could take its place.
articles.byline: By Greg Myre and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Rangers Take On Urban Woes in Wide Open Spaces
articles.snippet: Threats and assaults against forest rangers are soaring as growing cities in the West bump against public land.
articles.abstract: Threats and assaults against forest rangers are soaring as growing cities in the West bump against public land.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev., July 19 — For Dave Leveille, patrolling the biggest national forest in the contiguous United States has nothing to do with examining tree rings or dispensing hiking tips. He is a forest ranger with a badge and a 16-round sidearm, and every day brings fresh examples of the kind of unnatural things that people do in nature.

articles.headline: Taking the Taxi to Higher Heights
articles.snippet: For years, questions about the size of an air taxi market have been largely theoretical. But that will change this year.
articles.abstract: For years, questions about the size of an air taxi market have been largely theoretical. But that will change this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, July 25  Jam-packed planes. Endless delays. Long security lines. Sprints through an airport to make a connecting flight.

articles.headline: Israel Finding a Difficult Foe in Hezbollah
articles.snippet: A week ago, Israeli officials said in another week or two they would have incapacitated Hezbollah. That talk has largely stopped.
articles.abstract: A week ago, Israeli officials said in another week or two they would have incapacitated Hezbollah. That talk has largely stopped.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, July 25  A week ago, Israeli officials said their military had knocked out up to half of Hezbollah’s rocket launchers and suggested that another week or two would finish the job of incapacitating the Lebanese militia. That talk has largely stopped.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Goldman Finds Investing for Itself Rewarding
articles.snippet: A new focus at Goldman Sachs has exposed fault lines between the investment bankers and the private-equity bankers.
articles.abstract: A new focus at Goldman Sachs has exposed fault lines between the investment bankers and the private-equity bankers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private equity has paid off handsomely for Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former chief executive of Goldman Sachs.

articles.headline: Turning Back the Clock on Backdating
articles.snippet: Backdating option grants is really part of a larger problem that won’t go away even if some people end up going to jail.
articles.abstract: Backdating option grants is really part of a larger problem that won’t go away even if some people end up going to jail.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON a Friday night five years ago, a technology executive named Dave Rickey appeared on Maria Bartiromo’s weekly television show and delivered one of the more amazing performances in the history of CNBC.

articles.headline: Heart Pill to Be Sold by Itself
articles.snippet: Reversing a strategy that had drawn criticism from doctors, Pfizer says that it will apply for approval to sell a promising new heart treatment as a standalone pill -- rather than only in combination with Lipitor, Pfizer's best-selling cholesterol...
articles.abstract: Reversing a strategy that had drawn criticism from doctors, Pfizer says that it will apply for approval to sell a promising new heart treatment as a standalone pill -- rather than only in combination with Lipitor, Pfizer's best-selling cholesterol treatment.     The new drug, torcetrapib, is still being tested in clinical trials and is at least 18 months from federal approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reversing a strategy that had drawn criticism from doctors, Pfizer says that it will apply for approval to sell a promising new heart treatment as a standalone pill -- rather than only in combination with Lipitor, Pfizer's best-selling cholesterol treatment.

articles.headline: Taking the Taxi to Higher Heights
articles.snippet: Jam-packed planes. Endless delays. Long security lines. Sprints through an airport to make a connecting flight.      It is enough to make someone, particularly a business traveler, yearn for another option.
articles.abstract: Jam-packed planes. Endless delays. Long security lines. Sprints through an airport to make a connecting flight.      It is enough to make someone, particularly a business traveler, yearn for another option.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, July 25 - Jam-packed planes. Endless delays. Long security lines. Sprints through an airport to make a connecting flight.

articles.headline: Turning Back the Clock on Backdating
articles.snippet: ON a Friday night five years ago, a technology executive named Dave Rickey appeared on Maria Bartiromo's weekly television show and delivered one of the more amazing performances in the history of CNBC.     Like a lot of companies in early 2001, t...
articles.abstract: ON a Friday night five years ago, a technology executive named Dave Rickey appeared on Maria Bartiromo's weekly television show and delivered one of the more amazing performances in the history of CNBC.     Like a lot of companies in early 2001, the one Mr. Rickey ran -- a silicon chip maker called Applied Micro Circuits -- was going through tough times. Its customers were canceling orders for new equipment, and its stock had sunk from a high of more than $100 in the summer of 2000 to just $29 when Mr. Rickey sat down with Ms. Bartiromo.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON a Friday night five years ago, a technology executive named Dave Rickey appeared on Maria Bartiromo's weekly television show and delivered one of the more amazing performances in the history of CNBC.

articles.headline: Senate Removes Abortion Option for Young Girls
articles.snippet: The Senate passed legislation Tuesday that would make it a federal crime to help an under-age girl escape parental notification laws by crossing state lines to obtain an abortion.     The bill was approved on a 65-to-34 vote, with 14 Democrats joi...
articles.abstract: The Senate passed legislation Tuesday that would make it a federal crime to help an under-age girl escape parental notification laws by crossing state lines to obtain an abortion.     The bill was approved on a 65-to-34 vote, with 14 Democrats joining 51 Republicans in favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 25 - The Senate passed legislation Tuesday that would make it a federal crime to help an under-age girl escape parental notification laws by crossing state lines to obtain an abortion.

articles.headline: Goldman Finds Investing for Itself Rewarding
articles.snippet: Private equity has paid off handsomely for Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former chief executive of Goldman Sachs.     For the last two years, Mr. Paulson, now the Treasury secretary, has banked $24 million in investment returns from lucrative partners...
articles.abstract: Private equity has paid off handsomely for Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former chief executive of Goldman Sachs.     For the last two years, Mr. Paulson, now the Treasury secretary, has banked $24 million in investment returns from lucrative partnerships made available to top Goldman executives. The sudden flowering of these investments -- last year, Mr. Paulson's return was $12.7 million, according to the firm's 2006 proxy -- signals vividly how Goldman's growing private-equity business has been gushing profits not only for the firm's executives, but also for the investment bank as a whole.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private equity has paid off handsomely for Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former chief executive of Goldman Sachs.

articles.headline: Sales Slow for Homes New and Old
articles.snippet: Selling a new home is getting harder and harder: just ask the builders who are being forced these days to entice potential buyers with expensive inducements like free swimming pools and fancy kitchen cabinets.     At the same time, the torrid pace...
articles.abstract: Selling a new home is getting harder and harder: just ask the builders who are being forced these days to entice potential buyers with expensive inducements like free swimming pools and fancy kitchen cabinets.     At the same time, the torrid pace in the existing-home market is slackening, as prices are leveling off and properties are staying on the market a lot longer than they used to.
articles.lead_paragraph: Selling a new home is getting harder and harder: just ask the builders who are being forced these days to entice potential buyers with expensive inducements like free swimming pools and fancy kitchen cabinets.

articles.headline: White House Bill Proposes System to Try Detainees
articles.snippet: Legislation drafted by the Bush administration setting out new rules on bringing terror detainees to trial would allow hearsay evidence to be introduced unless it was deemed ''unreliable'' and would permit defendants to be excluded from their own ...
articles.abstract: Legislation drafted by the Bush administration setting out new rules on bringing terror detainees to trial would allow hearsay evidence to be introduced unless it was deemed ''unreliable'' and would permit defendants to be excluded from their own trials if necessary to protect national security, according to a copy of the proposal.     The bill, which officials said was being circulated within the administration, is not final, but it indicates the direction of the administration's approach for dealing with a Supreme Court decision that struck down the tribunals established to try terror suspects at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 25 - Legislation drafted by the Bush administration setting out new rules on bringing terror detainees to trial would allow hearsay evidence to be introduced unless it was deemed "unreliable" and would permit defendants to be excluded from their own trials if necessary to protect national security, according to a copy of the proposal.
articles.byline: By David S. Cloud and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Israel Finding a Difficult Foe in Hezbollah
articles.snippet: A week ago, Israeli officials said their military had knocked out up to half of Hezbollah's rocket launchers and suggested that another week or two would finish the job of incapacitating the Lebanese militia. That talk has largely stopped.     Hez...
articles.abstract: A week ago, Israeli officials said their military had knocked out up to half of Hezbollah's rocket launchers and suggested that another week or two would finish the job of incapacitating the Lebanese militia. That talk has largely stopped.     Hezbollah is still launching 100 rockets a day at Israel, nearly as many as it did at the start of the war. Soldiers return from forays into Lebanon saying the network of bunkers and tunnels is more sophisticated than expected. And Iranian-made long-range missiles apparently capable of hitting Tel Aviv remain in the Hezbollah arsenal.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, July 25 - A week ago, Israeli officials said their military had knocked out up to half of Hezbollah's rocket launchers and suggested that another week or two would finish the job of incapacitating the Lebanese militia. That talk has largely stopped.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Rangers Take On Urban Woes in Wide Open Spaces
articles.snippet: For Dave Leveille, patrolling the biggest national forest in the contiguous United States has nothing to do with examining tree rings or dispensing hiking tips. He is a forest ranger with a badge and a 16-round sidearm, and every day brings fresh ...
articles.abstract: For Dave Leveille, patrolling the biggest national forest in the contiguous United States has nothing to do with examining tree rings or dispensing hiking tips. He is a forest ranger with a badge and a 16-round sidearm, and every day brings fresh examples of the kind of unnatural things that people do in nature.      Mr. Leveille has been spat on, kicked, chased by snowmobilers and other off-road-vehicle riders. At least once a week, somebody calls him the kind of name that would make Smokey Bear blush. And what happens in Las Vegas or Reno does not stay there; often it ends up in the neighboring Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest, Mr. Leveille's six-million-acre beat.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev., July 19 - For Dave Leveille, patrolling the biggest national forest in the contiguous United States has nothing to do with examining tree rings or dispensing hiking tips. He is a forest ranger with a badge and a 16-round sidearm, and every day brings fresh examples of the kind of unnatural things that people do in nature.

articles.headline: Israel to Occupy Area of Lebanon as Security Zone
articles.snippet: Almost two weeks into its military assault on Hezbollah, Israel said Tuesday that it would occupy a strip inside southern Lebanon with ground troops until an international force could take its place.     The announcement raised the prospect of a m...
articles.abstract: Almost two weeks into its military assault on Hezbollah, Israel said Tuesday that it would occupy a strip inside southern Lebanon with ground troops until an international force could take its place.     The announcement raised the prospect of a more protracted Israeli involvement in Lebanon than the political and military leadership previously signaled or publicly sought. Officials have talked about limited raids into Lebanon, but now they seem ready to commit ground forces for at least weeks, if not months.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, July 25 - Almost two weeks into its military assault on Hezbollah, Israel said Tuesday that it would occupy a strip inside southern Lebanon with ground troops until an international force could take its place.
articles.byline: By Greg Myre and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Baghdad Chaos Pushes Bush to Shift U.S. Troops
articles.snippet: Saying the security situation in Baghdad remained ''terrible,'' President Bush announced an agreement with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Tuesday to significantly strengthen the United States military presence in the city.     The announce...
articles.abstract: Saying the security situation in Baghdad remained ''terrible,'' President Bush announced an agreement with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Tuesday to significantly strengthen the United States military presence in the city.     The announcement, presented at a joint news conference during Mr. Maliki's first visit to the White House since taking office in May, was a tacit admission that the Iraqi government had not succeeded in bringing stability to the capital, and that any major withdrawal of American troops soon remained unlikely.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 25 - Saying the security situation in Baghdad remained "terrible," President Bush announced an agreement with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Tuesday to significantly strengthen the United States military presence in the city.
